title: How to Choose the Best Leash for Your Dog
profile: Every dog owner takes their friendly pet on a walk or outside for some exercise and using a leash is often the most convenient way to do so. There are a wide variety of elements to consider when choosing a leash for your dog, from materials to styles to training. Understanding which materials and styles will best suit your current dog’s lifestyle will help make the most informed and appropriate decision possible.

step_items.content: Consider nylon. Nylon is the most common material that dog leashes are made of. They come in a large variety of colors, styles, lengths, and sizes. Nylon leashes are generally better for puppies as they can cause leash burn if you have a dog that can suddenly pull the leash from your hand. WH.performance.mark('step1_rendered');

Use durable chain leashes. Chain leashes are another cheap and affordable option, but often come with more drawbacks than a nylon leash. Although very durable, chain leashes can be difficult to hold and can cause complications for both you and your dog should they become tangled or knotted.

Try leather for a durable and comfortable leash. Leather leashes are not as popular and common as nylon or chain leashes, but are generally just as durable. Leather leashes also soften with time and are easier to grip should you have a dog that can have a strong pull. Leather leashes don’t tangle as often and provide a softer grip than nylon or chain leashes. Leather leashes come in two options, either flat or braided. Braided leashes tend to be a little lighter in weight, but there are no significant differences between either.
children: Leather leashes come in two options, either flat or braided. Braided leashes tend to be a little lighter in weight, but there are no significant differences between either.

step_items.content: Use a cotton leash when around water. Cotton leashes are perhaps the most difficult to find. However, cotton leashes are especially useful if your dog swims often as they hold up the best underwater or when wet. Cotton leashes, like nylon, can also cause leash burn if or when your dog pulls.

Consider using a standard style leash. Standard style leashes are the most common leashes and can be purchased at almost all dog leash vendors and pet stores. Although the most common, there are better leashes to be considered if you are training your dog or your dog has behavioral issues. X Research source Use standard leashes for high-energy large dogs as well as smaller dogs or puppies.
children: Use standard leashes for high-energy large dogs as well as smaller dogs or puppies.

step_items.content: Use retractable leashes to give your dog freedom to move. Retractable leashes are often made of nylon and have a range of lengths. Retractable dog leashes also give your dog more freedom to walk and give you less control to walk them. Consider using other leashes if you are trying to train your dog as it will be difficult to control them on a retractable leash. X Research source Retractable leashes are most common with small dogs or dogs with lower energy. Keep in mind that most dog trainers disapprove of retractable leashes because they teach the dog to pull on the lead. This is because the dog perceives they only have to pull to get where they want to go, so they don't learn to listen to the owner's commands to walk and to heel.

step_items.content: Try head collars to leash-train your dog. X Expert Source Dee HoultCertified Dog Behavior Consultant Expert Interview. 15 September 2020. Head collars are collars that slip over your dog’s nose while still allowing them to breathe, eat, and drink. Try using head collars for dogs who still need to be leash trained as they often give the best control with minimum risk. Head collars also require specific usage, so be sure to inquire with your vendor or pet store about proper use before fitting your dog and beginning to train them. X Research source Head collars control your dog by their neck and head, which means that if you are training them not pull on their leash that their collar needs to be properly fitted in order to minimize the risk of injury. step_items.content: Use harness collars if your dog is leash-trained. Harness collars do provide extra support for your dog, but they are most effective if your dog is already leash-trained. Harness collars come in a few different variations, some of which are better for shorter snouted or smaller dogs. They can also cause injury as harness collars pull from the center of the dog’s body, which can cause over-extension if pulled from the side. X Research source The two most popular style harness are the Easy Walk harness and the body harness. Be aware that a harness does not give you much control over a dog that pulls. If you have a large dog that pulls, then a collar or head harness is a better choice

step_items.content: Choose your leash. Once you become familiar with the different material and style choices you are ready to choose your leash. Take the level of your dog’s training, their age, size, and activity level into account when deciding on which leash is best for your dog. Consult your local pet store, vet, or online vendor about which leash will be most effective for your dog.

Consult your vet for recommendations. If your dog has health or behavioral problems your vet may have useful leash recommendations. Consider asking your vet if the leash you are interested in purchasing would be a good fit for your dog or if they have any specific recommendations. Ask your vet questions like, “Are there leashes I should get for my dog’s health issue?” “Do you recommend one leash more often than the rest?” or “Which vendor should I purchase my leash from?”
children: Ask your vet questions like, “Are there leashes I should get for my dog’s health issue?” “Do you recommend one leash more often than the rest?” or “Which vendor should I purchase my leash from?”

step_items.content: Go to your local pet store. Consult an employee at your local pet store about popular and common dog leashes. Most employees will also be able to recommend leashes based on your dog’s size, age, and energy level. Although they won’t be able to provide specific recommendations about your dog’s health or behavioral issues, most employees should be able to point you in the right direction. Ask the employee questions like, “Which leash do you sell the most of?” “Which leash would your recommend for behavioral training?” or “What leash should I get for my high energy dog?”
children: Ask the employee questions like, “Which leash do you sell the most of?” “Which leash would your recommend for behavioral training?” or “What leash should I get for my high energy dog?”

step_items.content: Shop for your leash online. Most pet stores and vendors will offer leashes to be purchased online. Shopping for leashes online will also allow you to see user comments and reviews about the quality, longevity, and effectiveness of each leash. Some online vendors also offer custom order leashes for specific or unusual sizes, or specific health issues.
